Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: SafePaths: A privacy-first contact tracing solution for early interventions of COVID-19 spread during the first wave and to minimize the second wave of the epidemic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this project is to develop and deploy a privacy-first digital solution for public health coordination including contact-tracing to curb pandemics like COVID-19 spread. The key is to provide location and context for citizens and public health experts. Current approaches operate on a trade-off between privacy and effectiveness, relying on general public broadcasting that introduces uncertainty in the information extracted or resorting to privacy-violating technologies that risk individual rights against stigmatization and surveillance. This project will break past this dichotomy by developing a technology-based solution for coordinating information on infection and possible transmission through contact-tracing while protecting the privacy rights of viral carriers and unexposed citizens.<br/><br/>Beyond assisting the containment of COVID-19 pandemic by contact tracing, this project will make empirical contributions to the fields of computing, healthcare, crisis response, and more. With privacy preservation being the key aspect of this project, contact tracing is achieved by using encrypted GPS trails and rotating Bluetooth identifiers. In this approach, redacted information of an infected individual is only shared while no information leaves the device of a healthy person. Specifically, this project will advance knowledge regarding: 1.) how cryptographic techniques can be implemented on ubiquitous platforms like smart phones through easy to use apps to efficiently use privatized data without leakage of any sensitive information; 2) how personal-technology solutions to societal crises can effectively influence behavior and consequently affect the outcome of such crises; and 3) how “split-learning”, a resource efficient distributed AI technique can be implemented with personal information on health, demographic, travel history, spatial context, and real-world engagement to perform private risk-assessment post contact-tracing to reduce false alarm rates. The solution is being built by a consortium of epidemiologists, engineers, data scientists, digital privacy evangelists, professors and researchers from reputable institutions. This is crucial to reduce disruption in socio-economic activity and keep panic under rationally controllable levels in response to future emergencies.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to design and develop contact tracing systems that are practical from a privacy and usability standpoint in order to achieve an increased adoption. We address various privacy constraints by developing novel contact tracing algorithms and integrate some of them in a system that is packaged into a smartphone user facing app. Specifically, we aim to design privacy preserving contact tracing algorithms that also provide outstanding computational and communication efficiency in order to enable its usability.

 

The project resulted in the development of privacy preserving set intersection algorithms for contact tracing. However, the algorithms are useful for various applications where comparison of information needs to be made between two individuals. We focused on developing different algorithms that trade-off between computation and communication between different entities involved in the contact tracing algorithm. This allows the stakeholders to choose a particular algorithm based on the underlying practical use case. Finally, we integrated some of these algorithms into a smartphone app that logs GPS and Bluetooth data securely and uses it for contact tracing.


This project fully supported one postdoctoral researcher and one graduate student partially. This support allowed PI and graduate students to present their work in workshops and conferences. The support for this project also helped in running a series of workshops on trusted pandemic technologies which invited various stakeholders from different domains related to public health including epidemiology, governance, privacy, technology, etc. The workshop series can be found here - https://responsibledata.ai/events/trust.
